Knowledge Point: Some morphemes have both subordinating and coordinating functions, e.g. ma (\sectref{ssec:ma}, \sectref{ssec:cond_ma}), and the presence of insubordination, usually with adhortative or optative function, confronts us with matrix and subordinate clauses that look the same. Insubordinate clauses are structurally identical to subordinate clauses, with the exception that they do not depend on a matrix clause (\sectref{ssec:Insub}). Apart from complement clauses, which are unambiguous, there are cases of two subordinate clauses coordinated by a conjunction, showing that they do not occupy the same slot (ex. \ref{ex:hapi_ma} in \sectref{ssec:hapi}). Furthermore, coordinate clauses cannot be fronted (though a coordinating conjunction may be the first element of a clause), whereas some subordinate ones can.
Content 1: \gll e=caihnan hapi ma a=bo vwa | \gls 1SG=know COMP SUBR 3SG=IRR do | \glt I know with certainty that he will do it.

Knowledge Point: Coordination reduction constructions, in the sense that subjects are omitted from consecutive coordinated clauses if they are the same, exist in Vamale (\ref{ex:co_ma}), contrary to the typical Oceanic pattern \parencite[517]{ross_morphosyntactic_2004}.

The same is the case for subordinate clauses, though an absence of subject means a more immediate sequence: compare (\ref{ex:sub_red}), where killing is the underlying purpose of the matrix verb, to (\ref{ex:ma_silaa1}), where raising children is a more general and long-term goal not immediately tied to going into the house.
Content 1: \gll le=hma wati-le ma xaa-le hnuuda-me cahni | \gls 3PL=arrive chase-3OBJ SUBR beat-3PL.OBJ upstream-DIR.CP here | \glt They came to hunt them in order to strike them coming here up the river.

Knowledge Point: To give an overview of a complex sentence, (\ref{ex:tree2}) shows a clause containing an equative clause, a relative clause, a verb phrase with an argument, and a second relative clause modifying the argument.
Content 1: \gll tha le li=a= le=xhwat xhwi li=nyu a= xhopwen ka li=apuli-aen | \gls ASS 3PL DEF.PL=REL= 3PL=almost eat DEF.PL=fish REL= big SBJ DEF.PL=person-DEM.DIST | \glt These people are the ones who almost eat/ate the big fish.

Knowledge Point: \caption{Tree-diagram of the sentence structure of example (\ref{ex:tree2}), with le \qu{3\gl{pl}} instead of li apuli-aen \qu{these people}}
Content 1: \gll tha le li=a= le=xhwat xhwi li=nyu a= xhopwen ka li=apuli-aen | \gls ASS 3PL DEF.PL=REL= 3PL=almost eat DEF.PL=fish REL= big SBJ DEF.PL=person-DEM.DIST | \glt These people are the ones who almost eat/ate the big fish.

Knowledge Point: Coordination of clauses in Vamale holds no deep secrets. The string of clauses is articulated via elements which, in many cases, also appear in the coordination of noun and verb phrases. Both clauses maintain the same word order as single clauses. Coordination reduction constructions which would remove subject marking, are rare. One case of this is (\ref{ex:co_ma}) below.

Contrary to most other coordinators, ma is not attested linking complete clauses, both with their own subject marking, TAM contour, etc. Instead, ma is a common coordinator for noun phrases, and is found with verb phrases as well. As for noun phrases, the clauses linked must be semantically part of the same group (\ref{ex:co_ma}). I mention ma here because ma vwa-tau is a coordination reduction construction: as the subject and the TAM contour are the same, indeed the verbs are semantically close (hunt and fish), vwa-tau \qu{fish} does not need any of the usual particles surrounding it.

The classic coordinators kona (\ref{ex:kona}) and kon (\ref{ex:kon}) both mean \qu{so, and then}, though ko na \qu{and/but \gl{dem}} also exists, identical in syntactic distribution and phonological shape. kona and kon are semantically close and present a similar form, and may in fact be allomorphs or free variants.
Content 2: \gll kon abe=kon xaahni ca=piece-abe ma abe=thake-bigo | \gls CNJ 1PL.EXCL=PROG watch INDF.PL=coin-1PL.EXCL SUBR 1PL.EXCL=throw-bingo | \glt And we're saving some money for ourselves to play bingo.

Knowledge Point: The coordinator hai is used in three contexts: to coordinate two noun phrases or clauses (introduced in \sectref{ssec:cntr_hai}), to close a clause, implying that a list of possibilities goes on (\ref{ex:final_a}), and to begin a clause that is in direct contrast with the preceding one (\ref{ex:hai_first}). In most unmarked scenarios, hai is realised {[a]}. The hai form cannot be substituted by a when contrasting two noun phrases hai X hai Y? \qu{X or Y?} (see \sectref{ssec:cntr_hai}), but is otherwise an allomorph of a. Note that in (\ref{ex:hai_ma}), hai coordinates two subordinate clauses introduced by ma.
Content 1: \gll naen mwa a xahmaen mwa a | \gls now REP CNJ tomorrow REP CNJ | \glt See you later, or tomorrow, or\ldots

Knowledge Point: ko \qu{on} is one of the most versatile particles in the language, i.e. ko appears with many different functions. Apart from a preposition \qu{on}, and an oblique marker, ko is also used on an interclausal level, ranging from the coordinating \qu{and, but} (\ref{ex:ko_but1}) and (\ref{ex:ko_but2}), to the subordinating, adjunct-adding \qu{because} (\ref{ex:ko_reason}).
The coordinator koin \qu{then} derives from the word koin \qu{end}, which exists as a noun and as a verb (\ref{ex:koin}).
If koin occurs before a VP, it seems to mean ``while", as in (\ref{ex:koin_while}).

kavi \qu{but} introduces a coordinate clause that contrasts strongly with the preceding one (\ref{ex:kavi}). While it most often coordinates two clauses, kavi is also attested at the beginning of an utterance, to contrast it with statements made immediately before in the conversation (\ref{ex:kavi2}).
Content 2: \gll kavi th=abe vwa nyeca i=teete | \gls but ASS=1PL.EXCL do in DEF.SG=aunty | \glt But we're doing [the funerary work] with the [deceased] Aunty in mind.

Knowledge Point: Most subordinate clauses, apart from complement and relative ones, are introduced by the neutral verbal subordinator ma, as in (\ref{ex:ma}), or by a complex form containing it, e.g. cama \qu{if (\gl{irr})} and ko-ma \qu{so that (lit. because-\gl{subr})}, see (\ref{ex:koma}).

Modal constructions in Vamale are to a large extent formed in the same way: a matrix clause consisting of a modal word, and the proposition modified by the modal word, i.e. a complement clause. While the complement clause usually takes subject index marking, the 3\gl{sg} form a merges with the subordinator ma and is used in contexts where the subject is unknown. In (\ref{ex:comp_ma}), the modal word is the stative verb xahnang \qu{good}, which introduces the desirable proposition (\qu{if I knew what you are talking about}).
Content 1: \gll xahnang m=e bo caihna-n hapi go=pala ko i=da | \gls good COMP=1SG IRR know-ANA COMP 2SG=speak OBL DEF.SG=what | \glt It would be good if I knew what you are talking about.

Knowledge Point: Modal words include in fact only two non-verbs: the deontic modal word goon \qu{enough} \rightarrow goon ma V... \qu{it is possible, it is allowed}, and xhwan \qu{bite, bit} \rightarrow xhwan ma V... \qu{barely, almost} (\ref{ex:xhwan e-goakan}). The other members are verbs. Some verbs are decategorialized and also exist as stative verbs with predicative function, e.g. xahnang \qu{good} and nyau \qu{bad}, see xahnang-eo \qu{I am good}.

However, na can be omitted (\ref{ex:hapi}), as can even hapi, in a context where the clause boundaries are otherwise clarified (\ref{ex:no hapi}). In the latter example, the main verb is fwajimwa-ke \qu{ask-\gl{tr}}, which is transitive but demands an Experiencer argument (the person asked). The other clause cannot be added with hapi, as the latter is governed by a semantically defined group of verbs, which does not include fwajimwake. Hence we have two clauses: matrix clause e fwajimwako and matrix clause kai a i vukin-ea. i vukin-ea, a nominalized form of the stative verb vukin- \qu{to be the cause}, is the predicate of the equative clause with kai, which is itself an content of the question fwajimwa-ko, but cannot be added to the main verb. The two clauses are distinguishable by prosody, as kai marks the beginning of a new pitch contour. Note that kai is fronted here, as it is the focussed element of the question; the unmarked order would be i vukin-ea kai?.

The complementizer hapi is not necessarily the only morpheme to subordinate a clause. In (\ref{ex:hapi_ma}), the speaker is more certain of the content of the irrealis subordinate clause than in the unmarked example (\ref{ex:hapi_a}).
Content 1: \gll e=caihnan hapi ma a=bo vwa | \gls 1SG=know COMP SUBR 3SG=IRR do | \glt I know with certainty that he will do it.
Content 2: \gll e=caihnan hapi a=bo vwa | \gls 1SG=know COMP 3SG=IRR do | \glt I know that he will do it.

Knowledge Point: Adverbial clauses are introduced with can, derived from ca-n \qu{in-\gl{nspec}} and are indistinguishable from matrix clauses, except that the former's verb does not take subject marking (\ref{ex:can}). Since the adverbial clause's subject must be the same as that of the matrix, the subject index proclitic is omitted. Aspect markers are rarely used, as the TAM contour is the same as the matrix clause's, but bwa \qu{\gl{ipfv}} was overheard. Stative verbs that retain their subject marking are not attested. This weak desententialization is somewhat unusual for Oceanic languages, which canonically do not desententialize their adverbial clauses at all \parencite[519]{ross_morphosyntactic_2004}.

If an adverbial clause comes after a verb's argument, especially if the resulting construction is long, a resumptive vwa \qu{do} may be introduced as an anaphoric host to the adverbial clause (\ref{ex:ma_silaa}).

If the relativized, inanimate noun phrase was already mentioned, it does not get mentioned again (\ref{ex:rel_no_rep}), unlike in Bwatoo (\ref{ex:rel_bwatoo}), where it reappears in the slot of its new syntactic function.
Content 1: \gll e=holeke nya-si-m li=fati a= go=vi | \gls 1SG=thank put-hand-2SG.POSS DEF.PL=word REL= 2SG=say | \glt I thank you for the words you said.
Content 2: \gll ðo tam̥ake anĩ mẽãta a ᵑgo θaxuti-a | \gls 1SG know DEF story REL 2SG tell-3SG.OBJ | \glt I know the story that you are telling. \citep[71]{rivierre_bwatoo_2006}

Knowledge Point: A relativized subject noun phrase which is the subject in the relative clause as well, is most often indexed on the subordinated verb, but the relativizer itself is commonly skipped (\ref{ex:tuu_mapu}).
Content 1: \gll tha vwa li=personnes le=caihnan tuu mapu | \gls ASS there.is DEF.PL=person 3SG=know pull bee | \glt There are people who know how to pull bees [= harvest honey].

Knowledge Point: Several relative clauses may follow one another, modifying the same noun phrase (\ref{ex:rs_rs}), but this was not attested outside elicitations.
Content 1: \gll e=holeke nya-si-m i=xawakhan [{a}= siim-ea] [{a}= go=nya-a] | \gls 1SG=thank put-hand-2SG.POSS DEF=dog REL= mange-3SG REL= 2SG=give-3SG.OBJ | \glt I thank you for the mangy dog you gave [me]. (lit. I give.thank.for to-you the dog that mangy-he that you-give-it)

Knowledge Point: A very common function of ma is to subordinate a purposive clause (\ref{ex:ma1}). This can be used with causative meanings, like in vwa, ma \ldots \qu{do, so that...} (see \sectref{sec:caus}), or alone.
Content 1: \gll a=nya s-ung m=e nya si-m | \gls 3SG=give BEN-1SG.POSS SUBR=1SG give BEN-2SG.POSS | \glt He gave it to me so that I would give it to you.

Knowledge Point: When preceding a matrix clause, ma and its derived form cama introduce a hypothetical situation (\ref{ex:ma3}, \ref{ex:ma4}). As can be seen in (\ref{ex:cama1}), ma and cama can be used interchangeably in some contexts. As far as a difference could be made out between ma and cama, cama seems to precede more markedly irrealis situations (\ref{ex:cama2}), whereas ma is also used to refer to traditions (\ref{ex:ma2}). This ma is probably the base form from which the insubordinator ma was derived (see \sectref{ssec:Insub}).
Cala is syntactically identical to cama and ma (\ref{ex:cala}). Semantically, cala is used only to introduce past situations firmly rooted in reality, and cama for everything else.

Subordinate clauses can also be linked to a matrix clause of which they are the cause. The subordinators used for this are ko \qu{because} described in \sectref{sec:conj_ko}, as well as vuki-n \qu{cause, stem}. The latter word acts both as a stative verb, when the reason is a participant themselves (\ref{ex:vukin-eong}), or as a subordinating particle, when the reason is an entire clause (\ref{ex:vukin}).

In order to mark a clause as adhortative (\ref{ex:adhort1}, \ref{ex:adhort2}), as a wish (\ref{ex:wish}), a regret (\ref{ex:signe}), or to diminish the speaker's assertiveness, the complementizer ma can be put at the very beginning of a clause without a preceding matrix clause.
Content 1: \gll ma gase=e-saam ko li=vaaya-n-gaa | \gls SUBR 1INCL=RECP-help OBL DEF.PL=work-POSS-1INCL.POSS | \glt May we help each other in our works.
Content 2: \gll ma gavwe=xaleke, ka caihna-n | \gls SUBR 2PL=see CNJ know-ANA | \glt May you look [at this custom] and know (acknowledge) it.
